description: Borrowed from Latin laureatus, from laurea (“laurel tree”), from laureus (“of laurel”), from laurus (“laurel”). Compare French lauréat.

entries.meaning: (sometimes postpositive) Crowned, or decked, with laurel.
examples: Although the post of poet laureate as we know it was not established until John Dryden's appointment in 1668,

entries.meaning: (dated) One crowned with laurel, such as a poet laureate or Nobel laureate.

verbs.description: laureate (third-person singular simple present laureates, present participle laureating, simple past and past participle laureated)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To honor with a wreath of laurel, as formerly was done in bestowing a degree at English universities.
